examples.text: Wash your colors separately from your darks and lights.
The charges … allege that the social network discriminates based on color …
… sat looking at her with wistful eyes, trying to see signs of hope in the faint color on Beth's cheeks.
… the USSR changed neither its colors nor its stripes during all of this …
… that color and force of style which were later to make him outstanding among American editors …
The play had a good deal of color to it.
His story has the color of truth.
the color and richness of the cello
"The lives of most of us have been colored by politics … "
a highly colored version of the facts
… call it progress; color it inevitable with shades of job security
His granddaughter Fernanda sat at his side, coloring with crayons.
"Rosetta [LeNoire] did more than dream of a theater with no color bar—she actually built one," he [Bill Clinton] said.
Dull colors are the rule for color-blind animals, like elephants and hippos and rhinos.
… the examiner in Seattle who had first looked at these capsules couldn't possibly have seen the green specks: he was color-blind.
It really was an awful garment, that pullover. It had a queasy zigzag pattern, in many strange, unhappy colors. It looked like something knitted as a present by a colorblind aunt.
We maintain no cash reserves, assuming we can borrow our way out of a crisis. We live as if color-blind to risk.
In color blindness which affects as many as 8 to 10 percent of men, a person may lose the ability to see all colors or merely the capacity to discriminate between certain hues.
"Colorblindness" is almost always a misnomer. In the vast majority of cases, people can still see many colors, but they can't discriminate as many as people with regular vision.

For [Justice John] Harlan, color blindness forbade the state from creating invidious racial categories; for Rehnquist (and Reagan and Steele), color blindness means racial neutrality—as if we live in a world where wishing makes prejudice go away.

Many sociologists, though, are extremely critical of colorblindness as an ideology. They argue that as the mechanisms that reproduce racial inequality have become more covert and obscure than they were during the era of open, legal segregation, the language of explicit racism has given way to a discourse of colorblindness.

They [critics] argue that since race is a major contributing factor in all sorts of societal outcomes, from who goes to jail to what educational opportunities a child has, to adopt color-blindness as an ideology is to ignore important discrepancies, thereby allowing them to fester.

examples.text: A wet piece of cloth covers the bulb of one, the , which is cooled by evaporation of water in the cloth. The other thermometer, a dry-bulb thermometer, measures the air temperature. The difference between the two thermometers' readings is used in a mathematical formula to determine the  and relative humidity.

examples.text: he had warning of his illness

The vivid orange, red, black and white color patterns on the wings are a monarch's advertisement to potential predators. This warning coloration enables a bird such as a blue jay, which might eat one poisonous monarch and become ill, to recognize and avoid the butterfly by sight alone in the future.
examples.koreanText: 날개의 선명한 주황색, 빨간색, 검은색, 흰색 무늬는 잠재적 포식자에게 알리는 제왕나비의 광고입니다. 이 경고색은 독이 있는 제왕나비를 먹고 병에 걸릴 수 있는 어치 같은 새가 앞으로 시각만으로 나비를 알아보고 피할 수 있게 해줍니다.

examples.text: Falling prices may be a warning sign of a recession.
examples.koreanText: 가격 하락은 경기 침체의 경고 신호일 수 있습니다.

examples.text: They gave me a word of warning about the slippery roads.
examples.koreanText: 도로가 미끄러울 수 있다는 경고의 말을 해주었습니다.

examples.text: I'm giving you fair warning that you had better not discuss politics at dinner tonight.
examples.koreanText: 오늘 저녁 식사 자리에서 정치 얘기는 하지 않는 게 좋을 것 같다는 경고를 드리고 싶네요.

examples.text: The suspect was given a Miranda warning.
… in 1951, the network began to unravel, and two of its members, Donald Maclean and Guy Burgess, prewarned by fellow conspirators, jumped the night ferry to St.-Malo …
examples.koreanText: ... 1951 년에 네트워크가 풀리기 시작했고, 동료 공모자들의 사전 경고를받은 두 명의 회원 인 Donald Maclean과 Guy Burgess는 세인트 말로로가는 야간 페리를 탔습니다 ...
